A piece of felt to cover the eye of a vicious horse
Any surface of semicircular or segmental form; especially, the piece of wall between the curves of a vault and its springing line
An iron shoe at the end of the stock of a gun carriage

lung.definition: An organ for aërial respiration; -- commonly in the plural

lung-grown.definition: Having lungs that adhere to the pleura

lunge.definition: A sudden thrust or pass, as with a sword
To cause to go round in a ring, as a horse, while holding his halter

lunged.definition: Having lungs, or breathing organs similar to lungs

lungfish.definition: Any fish belonging to the Dipnoi; -- so called because they have both lungs and gills

lungis.definition: A lingerer; a dull, drowsy fellow

lungoor.definition: A long-tailed monkey (Semnopithecus schislaceus), from the mountainous districts of India

lungworm.definition: Any one of several species of parasitic nematoid worms which infest the lungs and air passages of cattle, sheep, and other animals, often proving fatal.  The lungworm of cattle (Strongylus micrurus) and that of sheep (Strongylus filaria) are the best known

lungwort.definition: An herb of the genus Pulmonaria (Pulmonaria officinalis), of Europe; -- so called because the spotted appearance of the leaves resembles that of a diseased lung

lunicurrent.definition: Having relation to changes in currents that depend on the moon's phases

lunisolar.definition: Resulting from the united action, or pertaining to the mutual relations, of the sun and moon

lunistice.definition: The farthest point of the moon's northing and southing, in its monthly revolution

lunitidal.definition: Pertaining to tidal movements dependent on the moon

lunt.definition: The match cord formerly used in firing cannon

lunular.definition: Having a form like that of the new moon; shaped like a crescent; lunate

lunule.definition: Anything crescent-shaped; a crescent-shaped part or mark; a lunula; a lune

lunulet.definition: A small spot, shaped like a half-moon or crescent; as, the lunulet on the wings of many insects

lunulite.definition: Any bryozoan of the genus Lunulites, having a more or less circular form

lupercal.definition: Of or pertaining to the Lupercalia
A grotto on the Palatine Hill sacred to Lupercus, the Lycean Pan

lupercalia.definition: A feast of the Romans in honor of Lupercus, or Pan

lupine.definition: A leguminous plant of the genus Lupinus, especially Lupinus albus, the seeds of which have been used for food from ancient times. The common species of the Eastern United States is Lupinus perennis. There are many species in California

lupinin.definition: A glucoside found in the seeds of several species of lupine, and extracted as a yellowish white crystalline substance

lupinine.definition: An alkaloid found in several species of lupine (Lupinus luteus, Lupinus albus, etc.), and extracted as a bitter crystalline substance, having a formula C10H19NO.  Called also l-lupinine

lupulin.definition: A bitter principle extracted from hops
The fine yellow resinous powder found upon the strobiles or fruit of hops, and containing this bitter principle

lupuline.definition: An alkaloid extracted from hops as a colorless volatile liquid

lupulinic.definition: Pertaining to, or obtained from, hops; specifically, designating an acid obtained by the decomposition of lupulin

lupus.definition: originally, a cutaneous disease with the appearance of the skin having been gnawed, and occurring under two distinct forms.  Now used as a generic term for over ten distinguishable diseases having visible cutaneous symptoms
The Wolf, a constellation situated south of Scorpio

lurch.definition: To swallow or eat greedily; to devour; hence, to swallow up
An old game played with dice and counters; a variety of the game of tables
A double score in cribbage for the winner when his adversary has been left in the lurch
To leave in the lurch; to cheat
A sudden roll of a ship to one side, as in heavy weather; hence, a swaying or staggering movement to one side, as that by a drunken man
To roll or sway suddenly to one side, as a ship or a drunken man; to move forward while lurching
To withdraw to one side, or to a private place; to lurk
To dodge; to shift; to play tricks

lurcher.definition: One that lurches or lies in wait; one who watches to pilfer, or to betray or entrap; one who lurks; a lurker; a poacher
One of a mongrel breed of dogs said to have been a cross between the sheep dog, greyhound, and spaniel.  It hunts game silently, by scent, and is often used by poachers

lurchline.definition: The line by which a fowling net was pulled over so as to inclose the birds

lure.definition: A contrivance somewhat resembling a bird, and often baited with raw meat; -- used by falconers in recalling hawks
Any enticement; that which invites by the prospect of advantage or pleasure; a decoy
To draw to the lure; hence, to allure or invite by means of anything that promises pleasure or advantage; to entice; to attract
To recall a hawk or other animal

lurg.definition: A large marine annelid (Nephthys cæca), inhabiting the sandy shores of Europe and America. It is whitish, with a pearly luster, and grows to the length of eight or ten inches

lurid.definition: Pale yellow; ghastly pale; wan; gloomy; dismal
Having a brown color tinged with red, as of flame seen through smoke
Of a color tinged with purple, yellow, and gray
Vivid, sensational, or shocking; graphic or melodramatic; as, the lurid details of a murder

lurk.definition: To lie hidden; to lie in wait

lurry.definition: A confused heap; a throng, as of persons; a jumble, as of sounds

luscinia.definition: A genus of birds including the nightingale Luscinia megarhyncos

luscious.definition: Sweet; delicious; very grateful to the taste; toothsome; excessively sweet or rich

lusern.definition: A lynx. See 1st Lucern and Loup-cervier

lush.definition: Characterized by abundance or luxurience; rich

lusitania.definition: An ancient region and Roman province of the Iberian peninsula, corresponding roughly to modern Portugal and parts of Spain

lusitanian.definition: Pertaining to Lusitania, the ancient name of the region almost coinciding with Portugal

lussheburgh.definition: A spurious coin of light weight imported into England from Luxemburg, or Lussheburgh, as it was formerly called

lust.definition: Longing desire; eagerness to possess or enjoy; -- in a had sense; as, the lust of gain
Licentious craving; a strong sexual appetite
To have an eager, passionate, and especially an inordinate or sinful desire, as for the gratification of the sexual appetite or of covetousness; -- often with after

luster.definition: A period of five years; a lustrum
A candlestick, chandelier, girandole, or the like, generally of an ornamental character
The appearance of the surface of a mineral as affected by, or dependent upon, peculiarities of its reflecting qualities
A substance which imparts luster to a surface, as graphite and some of the glazes
A fabric of wool and cotton with a lustrous surface, -- used for women's dresses

lustering.definition: The act or process of imparting a luster, as to pottery
The brightening of a metal in the crucible when it becomes pure, as in certain refining processes

lustful.definition: Full of lust; excited by lust
Exciting lust; characterized by lust or sensuality

lustihood.definition: State of being lusty; vigor of body

lustily.definition: In a lusty or vigorous manner

lustiness.definition: State of being lusty; vigor; strength

lustral.definition: Of or pertaining to, or used for, purification; as, lustral days; lustral water
Of or pertaining to a lustrum

lustrate.definition: To make clear or pure by means of a propitiatory offering; to purify

lustration.definition: The act of lustrating or purifying
A sacrifice, or ceremony, by which cities, fields, armies, or people, defiled by crimes, pestilence, or other cause of uncleanness, were purified

lustrical.definition: Pertaining to, or used for, purification

lustring.definition: A kind of glossy silk fabric. See Lutestring

lustrum.definition: A lustration or purification, especially the purification of the whole Roman people, which was made by the censors once in five years

lusty.definition: Exhibiting lust or vigor; stout; strong; vigorous; robust; healthful; able of body

lusus naturae.definition: Sport or freak of nature; a deformed or unnatural production

lutanist.definition: A person that plays on the lute

lutarious.definition: Of, pertaining to, or like, mud; living in mud

lutation.definition: The act or method of luting vessels

lute.definition: A cement of clay or other tenacious infusible substance for sealing joints in apparatus, or the mouths of vessels or tubes, or for coating the bodies of retorts, etc., when exposed to heat; -- called also luting
A packing ring, as of rubber, for fruit jars, etc
A straight-edged piece of wood for striking off superfluous clay from mold
To close or seal with lute; as, to lute on the cover of a crucible; to lute a joint

A stringed instrument formerly much in use. It consists of four parts, namely, the table or front, the body, having nine or ten ribs or “sides,” arranged like the divisions of a melon, the neck, which has nine or ten frets or divisions, and the head, or cross, in which the screws for tuning are inserted. The strings are struck with the right hand, and with the left the stops are pressed
To play on a lute, or as on a lute

lutecium.definition: same as Lutetium; -- an older spelling

luteic.definition: Pertaining to, or derived from, weld (Reseda luteola)

lutein.definition: A substance of a strongly marked yellow color, extracted from the yolk of eggs, and from the tissue of the corpus luteum

luteo-.definition: A combining form signifying orange yellow or brownish yellow

luteocobaltic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of cobalt having a yellow color.  Cf. Cobaltic

luteolin.definition: A yellow dyestuff obtained from the foliage of the dyer's broom (Reseda luteola)

luteous.definition: Yellowish; more or less like buff

luter.definition: One who plays on a lute

lutestring.definition: A plain, stout, lustrous silk, used for ladies' dresses and for ribbon

lutetium.definition: A metallic element separated from ytterbium in 1907, by Urbain in Paris and by von Welsbach in Vienna.  It is a member of the Lanthanide rare earth group. Symbol, Lu; atomic number 71; atomic weight 174.967 [C=12.011].  Previously spelled Lutecium

lutheran.definition: Of or pertaining to Luther; adhering to the doctrines of Luther or the Lutheran Church
One who accepts or adheres to the doctrines of Luther or the Lutheran Church

lutheranism.definition: The doctrines taught by Luther or held by the Lutheran Church

luthier.definition: One who makes wooden stringed instruments, such as violins, guitars, etc

lutidine.definition: Any one of several metameric alkaloids, C5H3N.(CH3)2, of the pyridine series, obtained from bone oil as liquids, and having peculiar pungent odors. These alkaloids are also called respectively dimethyl pyridine, ethyl pyridine, etc

lutist.definition: One who plays on a lute

lutra.definition: A genus which in some classifications considered a genus of the subfamily Lutrinae

lutrinae.definition: A subdivision of mammals including the otters; it is not used in some classifications

lutulence.definition: The state or quality of being lutulent

lutzen.definition: A battle in the Thirty Years' War (1632) at which the Swedes under King Gustavus Adolphus defeated the Imperialists under Wallenstein, and in which Adolphus was killed

luvaridae.definition: A natural family including the louvars

luvarus.definition: The type genus of the Luvaridae

lux.definition: To put out of joint; to luxate

luxate.definition: To displace, or remove from its proper place, as a joint; to put out of joint; to dislocate

luxation.definition: The act of luxating, or the state of being luxated; a dislocation

luxembourger.definition: a native or inhabitant of Luxembourg

luxembourgian.definition: of or pertaining to Luxembourg (definition 2); as, Luxembourgian food

luxemburger.definition: a native or inhabitant of Luxembourg
of or pertaining to Luxemburg; as, Luxemburger streets
of or pertaining to Luxemburg (definition 2); as, Luxemburger castles
of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Luxemburg; as, our Luxemburger neighbors

luxullianite.definition: A kind of granite from Luxullian, Cornwall, characterized by the presence of radiating groups of minute tourmaline crystals

luxuria.definition: self-indulgent sexual desire (personified as one of the deadly sins)

luxuriance.definition: The state or quality of being luxuriant; rank, vigorous growth; excessive abundance produced by rank growth

luxuriancy.definition: The state or quality of being luxuriant; luxuriance

luxuriant.definition: Exuberant in growth; rank; excessive; profuse; very abundant; as, a luxuriant growth of grass; luxuriant foliage
Producing luxuriant growth; very fertile; -- of soil
Having or producing an abundance of elaborate details; unrestrained; -- of imagery or ornamentation

luxuriate.definition: To grow exuberantly; to grow to superfluous abundance
To feed or live luxuriously; as, the herds luxuriate in the pastures
To indulge with unrestrained delight and freedom; as, to luxuriate in description

luxuriation.definition: The act or process of luxuriating

luxurious.definition: Of or pertaining to luxury; ministering to luxury; supplied with the conditions of luxury; as, a luxurious life; a luxurious table; luxurious ease

luxury.definition: A free indulgence in costly food, dress, furniture, or anything expensive which gratifies the appetites or tastes

Anything which pleases the senses, is not necessary for life, and is also costly, or difficult to obtain; an expensive rarity; as, silks, jewels, and rare fruits are luxuries; in some countries ice is a great luxury.  Contrasted to necessity

luz.definition: A bone of the human body which was supposed by certain Rabbinical writers to be indestructible. Its location was a matter of dispute

lx.definition: the Roman numeral representation of sixty; six times ten; -- a determinate quantifier

lxx.definition: the Roman numeral representation of seventy; seven times ten; -- a determinate quantifier

lxxx.definition: the Roman numeral representation of eighty; eight times ten; -- a determinate quantifier

lycaena.definition: The type genus of the Lycaenidae; small slender butterflies with upper surface of wings usually metallic blue or green or copper

lycaenid.definition: any of various butterflies of the family Lycaenidae

lycaenidae.definition: A natural family of small usually brilliantly colored butterflies; males have short forelegs

lycaeon.definition: A genus of canids including the African hunting dog

lycanthrope.definition: A human being fabled to have been changed into a wolf; a werewolf

lycanthropist.definition: One affected by the disease lycanthropy

lycanthropy.definition: The supposed act of turning one's self or another person into a wolf
A kind of erratic melancholy, in which the patient imagines himself a wolf, and imitates the actions of that animal

lycee.definition: A French lyceum, or secondary school for students intermediate between elementary school and college, supported by the French government, for preparing students for the university
synonyms: Syn. -- secondary school, lyceum, Gymnasium, middle school.

lyceum.definition: A place of exercise with covered walks, in the suburbs of Athens, where Aristotle taught philosophy
A house or apartment appropriated to instruction by lectures or disquisitions
A higher school, in Europe, which prepares youths for the university
An association for debate and literary improvement

lychnis.definition: A genus of Old World plants belonging to the Pink family (Caryophyllaceæ).  Most of the species have brilliantly colored flowers and cottony leaves, which may have anciently served as wicks for lamps.  The botanical name is in common use for the garden species.  The corn cockle (Lychnis Githago) is a common weed in wheat fields

lychnobite.definition: One who labors at night and sleeps in the day

lychnoscope.definition: Same as Low side window, under Low, a

lycine.definition: A weak base identical with betaine; -- so called because found in the boxthorn (Lycium barbarum). See Betaine

lycium.definition: A genus of deciduous and evergreen shrubs often spiny; cosmopolitan in temperate and subtropical regions

lycoperdaceae.definition: A natural family of fungi including the genus Lycoperdon, consisting of puffballs

lycoperdales.definition: A small order of basidiomycetous fungi having fleshy often globose fruiting bodies: puffpalls; earthstars

lycoperdon.definition: A genus of fungi, remarkable for the great quantity of spores, forming a fine dust, which is thrown out like smoke when the plant is compressed or burst; puffball

lycophyta.definition: A term used in some classifications for the class Lycopsida: club mosses

lycopod.definition: A plant of the genus Lycopodium

lycopodiaceous.definition: Belonging, or relating, to the Lycopodiaceæ, an order of cryptogamous plants (called also club mosses) with branching stems, and small, crowded, one-nerved, and usually pointed leaves

lycopodineae.definition: An alternative designation for the class Lycopsida

lycopodite.definition: An old name for a fossil club moss

lycopodium.definition: A genus of mosslike plants, the type of the order Lycopodiaceæ; club moss

lycopsida.definition: The class including club mosses and related forms: includes Lycopodiales; Isoetales; Selaginellales; and extinct Lepidodendrales; sometimes considered a subdivision of Tracheophyta
synonyms: Syn. -- class Lycopsida, Lycopodiate, class Lycopodiate.

lycopus.definition: A small genus of nonaromatic herbs of the mint family

lycosa.definition: The type genus of the family Lycosidae

lycosidae.definition: The natural family of arachnids including the wolf spiders

lyddite.definition: A high explosive consisting principally of picric acid, used as a shell explosive in the British service; -- so named from the proving grounds at Lydd, England

lydian.definition: Of or pertaining to Lydia, a country of Asia Minor, or to its inhabitants; hence, soft; effeminate; -- said especially of one of the ancient Greek modes or keys, the music in which was of a soft, pathetic, or voluptuous character

lydine.definition: A violet dye derived from aniline

lye.definition: A strong caustic alkaline solution of potassium salts, obtained by leaching wood ashes. It is much used in making soap, etc
Sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide, or a concentrated aqueous solution of either compound
A short side line, connected with the main line; a turn-out; a siding

lyencephala.definition: A group of Mammalia, including the marsupials and monotremes; -- so called because the corpus callosum is rudimentary

lyencephalous.definition: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Lyencephala

lygaeidae.definition: A natural family comprising the lygaeid bugs

lyginopteridales.definition: An order of fossil gymnospermous trees or climbing plants from the Devonian: the seed ferns
synonyms: Syn. -- Cycadofilicales, order Cycadofilicales, order Lyginopteridales.

lyginopteris.definition: A genus of fossil seed ferns of the Carboniferous

lygodium.definition: A genus of ferns with twining or climbing fronds, bearing stalked and variously-lobed divisions in pairs

lying.definition: of Lie, to tell a falsehood
of Lie, to be supported horizontally

lying-in.definition: The state attending, and consequent to, childbirth; confinement; as, a lying-in hospital
The act of bearing a child

lym.definition: A dog held in a leam; a bloodhound; a limehound

lymantriid.definition: A dull-colored moth whose larvae have tufts of hair on the body and feed on the leaves of many deciduous trees

lymantriidae.definition: The natural family comprising the tussock moths

lyme grass.definition: A coarse perennial grass of several species of Elymus, esp. Elymus Canadensis, and the European Elymus arenarius

lymph.definition: A spring of water; hence, water, or a pure, transparent liquid like water

An alkaline colorless fluid, contained in the lymphatic vessels, coagulable like blood, but free from red blood corpuscles. It is absorbed from the various tissues and organs of the body, and is finally discharged by the thoracic and right lymphatic ducts into the great veins near the heart
A fibrinous material exuded from the blood vessels in inflammation. In the process of healing it is either absorbed, or is converted into connective tissue binding the inflamed surfaces together
A fluid containing certain products resulting from the growth of specific microorganisms upon some culture medium, and supposed to be possessed of curative properties

lymphadenitis.definition: Inflammation of the lymphatic glands; -- called also lymphitis

lymphangial.definition: Of or pertaining to the lymphatics, or lymphoid tissue; lymphatic

lymphatic.definition: pertaining to, containing, or conveying lymph
One of the lymphatic or absorbent vessels, which carry lymph and discharge it into the veins; lymph duct; lymphatic duct

lymphogenic.definition: Connected with, or formed in, the lymphatic glands

lymphography.definition: A description of the lymphatic vessels, their origin and uses

lymphoid.definition: Resembling lymph; also, resembling a lymphatic gland; adenoid; as, lymphoid tissue

lymphoma.definition: A tumor having a structure resembling that of a lymphatic gland; -- called also lymphadenoma

lyncean.definition: Of or pertaining to the lynx

lynch.definition: To inflict punishment upon, especially death, without the forms of law, as when a mob captures and hangs a suspected person. See Lynch law

lynch law.definition: The act or practice by private persons of inflicting punishment for crimes or offenses, without due process of law

lynx.definition: Any one of several species of feline animals of the genus Felis, and subgenus Lynx. They have a short tail, and usually a pencil of hair on the tip of the ears

lyonia.definition: A genus of evergreen or deciduous shrubs or small trees of the U. S. to the Antilles and eastern Asia to Himalaya

lyonnais.definition: a former province of east central France; now administered by Rhone-Alpes

lyonnaise.definition: Applied to boiled potatoes cut into small pieces and heated in oil or butter.  They are usually flavored with onion and parsley

lyophilize.definition: to freeze-dry; -- a technique used to dry serum, tissue, unstable chemicals and other sensitive materials

lyophilized.definition: dried by freezing and subsequent evaporation of the water in a high vacuum; -- used of tissue or blood or serum or other biological or sensitive substances

lyopomata.definition: An order of brachiopods, in which the valves of shell are not articulated by a hinge.  It includes the Lingula, Discina, and allied forms

lyra.definition: A northern constellation, the Harp, containing a white star of the first magnitude, called Alpha Lyræ, or Vega
The middle portion of the ventral surface of the fornix of the brain; -- so called from the arrangement of the lines with which it is marked in the human brain

lyrate.definition: Lyre-shaped, or spatulate and oblong, with small lobes toward the base; as, a lyrate leaf
Shaped like a lyre, as the tail of the blackcock, or that of the lyre bird

lyre.definition: A stringed instrument of music; a kind of harp much used by the ancients, as an accompaniment to poetry
One of the constellations; Lyra. See Lyra

lyre bird.definition: Any one of two or three species of Australian birds of the genus Menura. The male is remarkable for having the sixteen tail feathers very long and, when spread, arranged in the form of a lyre. The common lyre bird (Menura superba), inhabiting New South Wales, is about the size of a grouse. Its general color is brown, with rufous color on the throat, wings, tail coverts and tail. Called also lyre pheasant and lyre-tail

lyreflower.definition: A garden plant (Dicentra spectabilis) having deep-pink drooping heart-shaped flowers

lyric.definition: Of or pertaining to a lyre or harp
Fitted to be sung to the lyre
expressing deep personal emotion; -- said especially of poetry which expresses the individual emotions of the poet; as, the dancer's lyrical performance
A lyric poem; a lyrical composition
A verse of the kind usually employed in lyric poetry; -- used chiefly in the plural

lyricality.definition: the property of being suitable for singing

lyrid.definition: One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because the apparent path among the stars if traced backwards crosses the constellation Lyra

lyrie.definition: A European fish (Peristethus cataphractum), having the body covered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in front of the nose; -- called also noble, pluck, pogge, sea poacher, and armed bullhead

lyriferous.definition: Having a lyre-shaped shoulder girdle, as certain fishes

lyrism.definition: The act of playing on a lyre or harp

lyrist.definition: A musician who plays on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyrical poetry

lysichiton.definition: A genus of plants including one of the skunk cabbages

lysiloma.definition: A small genus of tropical American trees and shrubs with pinnate leaves and flat straight pods

lysimachia.definition: a cosmopolitan genus of plants, including some of the loosestrifes, found in damp or swampy terrain having usually yellow flowers; they are inclined to be invasive

lysimeter.definition: An instrument for measuring the water that percolates through a certain depth of soil

lysis.definition: The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not marked by abrupt change

lyterian.definition: Terminating a disease; indicating the end of a disease

lythe.definition: The European pollack; -- called also laith, and leet

lytta.definition: A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axis of the tongue in many mammals, as the dog
